questions.article: The way in which individual elements are balanced within a photographic image tends to affect how viewers perceive it: symmetry tends to give the elements equal importance, asymmetry emphasizes differences, and radial balance (organizing the elements around a central point) emphasizes the center over the periphery. What a photograph conveys is therefore largely _____ how it is balanced.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article: Stars form in cloudlike swirls of gas and dust that cannot be touched, but astrophysicist Nia Imara believes these formations need not remain completely ______ to researchers: she uses simulation data and sophisticated 3D printers to produce interactive models of these stellar nurseries.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article: The Stock Exchange of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand, is a dedicated exchange for investing in companies operating in Thailand, ensuring those companies receive certain regulatory oversight. Knowing this can ______ potential investors’ worries about bureaucratic minutiae and thereby allow them to instead focus on identifying sound business opportunities.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article: The tendency to group authors together into distinct literary movements often encourages literary scholars to ______ subtleties in an author's style. Those studying the works of Amos Bronson Alcott, for instance, may inadvertently overlook nuances in his work by focusing only on the most obvious ways in which his style corresponds to transcendentalism.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article:
The following text is from José Rizal's 1891 novel The Reign of Greed (translated by Charles Derbyshire in 1912).

A lady accompanied by her husband entered at that moment and took her place in one of the two vacant boxes. She had the air of a queen and gazed disdainfully at the whole house, as if to say, “I've come later than all of you, you crowd of upstarts and provincials, I've come later than you!" There are persons who go to the theater like the contestants in a mule-race: the last one in, wins, and we know very sensible men who would ascend the scaffold rather than enter a theater before the first act.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It illustrates the lady's contemptuous attitude toward the other people in the theater.

options.name: B
options.content: It helps explain why some people are especially perceptive of the social dynamics at theaters.

options.name: C
options.content: It emphasizes a character's dedication to her career.

options.name: D
options.content: It conveys the urgency some theater patrons feel to be the first ones to arrive at a performance.

questions.correct: It illustrates the lady's contemptuous attitude toward the other people in the theater.

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Louise Erdrich's 2020 novel The Night Watchman. Louis Pipestone is collecting signatures for a petition from fellow members of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa on the tribe's reservation in North Dakota.

Louis Pipestone tended the petition like a garden. He kept it with him at all times. In town, his eyes sharpened when he noticed a tribal member who hadn't yet signed. Wherever they were—at the gas pump, mercantile [general store], at Henry's [Café], on the road, or outside the clinic and hospital—Louis cornered them. If they were waiting for a baby to be born, he'd have them sign. If they were laughing, if they were arguing, if they were taking a child home from school, they signed.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To show that attitudes toward the petition within the tribal community change over time

options.name: B
options.content: To demonstrate that most tribal members are enthusiastic about signing the petition

options.name: C
options.content: To portray Louis Pipestone's strong commitment to collecting signatures for the petition

options.name: D
options.content: To suggest that some tribal members refuse to sign the petition because they dislike Louis Pipestone

questions.correct: To portray Louis Pipestone's strong commitment to collecting signatures for the petition

questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It conveys Don Jerónimo's lack of interest in continuing to support playwrights.

options.name: B
options.content: It explains Don Jerónimo's view of the quality of theatrical works of the time.

options.name: C
options.content: It creates a contrast between the talent of a young playwright and that of Don Jerónimo.

options.name: D
options.content: It emphasizes the degree to which Don Jerónimo's support is consequential for inexperienced playwrights.

questions.correct: It emphasizes the degree to which Don Jerónimo's support is consequential for inexperienced playwrights.

questions.article: A contraction of "you all," the pronoun "y'all" has long been used as a plural version of "you" in the South and in Black communities around the US. In recent decades, most other English-speaking communities in the US have begun to use "y'all." What explains its rise in popularity? Many varieties of English have no pronoun that specifically addresses more than one person and instead must use "you" to address both one person and more than one. But "y'all" always refers to two or more people. As a result, it conveys the speaker's meaning more precisely than "you" can.
questions.question: Which question does the text most directly attempt to answer?

options.name: A
options.content: How many other plural versions of the pronoun "you" are there in English, besides "y'all"?

options.name: B
options.content: When was the first recorded use of the pronoun "y'all" in the English language?

options.name: C
options.content: Is "y'all" commonly used in English-speaking regions of the world besides the US?

options.name: D
options.content: Why has the pronoun "y'all" become more widely used in the US?

questions.correct: Why has the pronoun "y'all" become more widely used in the US?

questions.article: Many people use the trademark “Kleenex" to refer generally to facial tissue rather than specifically to products made by Kimberly-Clark, the company that owns the trademark. As legal experts note, this may pose a problem for Kimberly-Clark. In the US, courts can cancel a trademark if they decide that its meaning is no longer specific to the trademark owner's products. If “Kleenex" were judged to have become a generic term, as “cellophane” was, other companies would be free to use it to promote similar products, making it harder for Kimberly-Clark to stand out from competitors.
questions.question: What does the text suggest about the term “cellophane"?

options.name: A
options.content: It is the subject of great debate among legal experts.

options.name: B
options.content: It once referred to a specific product made by a particular company.

options.name: C
options.content: It has recently become surprisingly popular for unknown reasons.

options.name: D
options.content: It was never intended by its creator to be used as a trademark.

questions.correct: It once referred to a specific product made by a particular company.

questions.article: The SCAD Museum of Art in Savannah, Georgia, has around 4,500 works of art. Digital images of hundreds of those works have been put online through the museum's website and the Google Arts & Culture project. One of the images is of The Card Game, a painting by Jacob Lawrence. In a paper, a student claims that putting a work from the museum online increases the number of people who experience that work.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the underlined claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Many people who have been to Savannah say that the SCAD Museum of Art is worth visiting.

options.name: B
options.content: Each year, more people access the online image of The Card Game than visit the SCAD Museum of Art in person.

options.name: C
options.content: The SCAD Museum of Art has several works by Jacob Lawrence.

options.name: D
options.content: The Card Game has been praised by some art critics.

questions.correct: Each year, more people access the online image of The Card Game than visit the SCAD Museum of Art in person.

questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the example?

questions.article: It is common for freshwater lakes near or above a latitude of 45° north of the equator, like Opeongo Lake in Canada, to accumulate surface ice in winter. The amount and duration of ice depends on many factors, including local weather conditions as well as the lake's depth, volume, and surface area, but a climate researcher claims that some lakes in these latitudes have seen a decline in the duration of ice between the early 1980s and the mid-2000s. She cites as a typical example ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the researcher's example?

options.name: A
options.content: both Lake Neusiedl and Oulujärvi, which had fewer than 195 days of ice in the winter of 1980-81.

options.name: B
options.content: Oulujärvi, which had fewer days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980-81.

options.name: C
options.content: Lake Neusiedl, which had more days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980-81.

options.name: D
options.content: both Lake Neusiedl and Oulujärvi, which had more than 100 days of ice in the winter of 2005-06.

questions.correct: Oulujärvi, which had fewer days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980-81.

questions.article: Veronica L. Bura, Akito Y. Kawahara, and Jaye E. Yack investigated the evolution and function of sound production in silk moth and hawk moth caterpillars. They found that during harmless simulated attacks on isolated caterpillars, 33% of the tested species produced sound, which ranged from clicks in Manduca pellenia to vocalizations in Sphecodina abbottii. Although some insects use sound to communicate with members of the same species, the researchers claim that the caterpillar sounds recorded in their study are directed primarily at predators.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Bura and colleagues' claim?

options.name: A
options.content: None of the species that emitted sounds did so before the simulated attacks, and nearly all stopped emitting sounds within ten seconds after the attacks.

options.name: B
options.content: In most cases, the sound that a caterpillar species produced during simulated attacks was not produced by other caterpillar species during simulated attacks.

options.name: C
options.content: Caterpillar clicks were emitted in a frequency detectable by birds that prey on caterpillars, but caterpillar vocalizations were not.

options.name: D
options.content: Each caterpillar species tended to produce one sound during simulated attacks, although individuals occasionally made a variety of other sounds during simulated attacks as well.

questions.correct: None of the species that emitted sounds did so before the simulated attacks, and nearly all stopped emitting sounds within ten seconds after the attacks.

questions.article: Over 600 languages are spoken in New York City in addition to English—one can find Aromanian spoken in the neighborhood of Ridgewood, or Hindi in Gramercy Park. Many immigrants from north China, where Mandarin is the primary language, reside in the neighborhood of Flushing (part of New York City's borough of Queens) while those who emigrated from south China, where many people speak Cantonese or Fuzhounese as a first language, tend to reside in Chinatown, in the borough of Manhattan. Among speakers of Chinese languages, those in Flushing tend to speak Mandarin as their primary language while those in Chinatown tend to speak Cantonese or Fuzhounese as their primary language. This is most likely because ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Chinese immigrants who emigrated to New York City many years ago are more likely to speak several Chinese languages than are more recent Chinese immigrants.

options.name: B
options.content: There are geographic differences in primary language within China that are reflected in the settlement patterns of Chinese immigrants in New York City.

options.name: C
options.content: Chinese immigrants regularly change their residences between Queens and Manhattan after they emigrate, rather than staying in one borough.

options.name: D
options.content: Taken together, there are more Cantonese and Fuzhounese speakers among Chinese immigrants in New York City than there are Mandarin speakers.

questions.correct: There are geographic differences in primary language within China that are reflected in the settlement patterns of Chinese immigrants in New York City.

questions.article: An upcoming exhibition will showcase Vincent van Gogh's drawing Snowy Landscape with Stooping Woman, which Van Gogh               in the city of Nuenen nearly 150 years ago.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: While the greater adjutant can be found in places like the Chao Phraya River in Thailand and the Teknaf Game Reserve in Bangladesh, more than 80 percent of this endangered stork species is found in Assam, India. There, wildlife biologist Dr. Purnima Devi Barman is on the front lines of conservation efforts that—through community involvement and scientific ______ aim to bring adjutants back from near extinction.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: In 1987, chemist Ahmed Zewail devised a novel technique in optical spectroscopy that allowed him to study ultrafast chemical reactions occurring within molecules. Years later, he ______ for this groundbreaking research with the Wolf Prize in Chemistry and the Robert A. Welch Award and hence would become known as the father of femtochemistry.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: Navajo artist Sally Black's mastery of traditional weaving techniques is apparent in her expertly crafted baskets, which typically are woven from sumac (a textured and flexible material) and ______ bold colors.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: Solarpunk is an art movement that imagines renewable energy-powered technology infused complementarily into nature. In Paolo Bacigalupi's solarpunk short story "Eficiency," an artificial intelligence that absorbs sustainable energies, redistributing them through intricate networks of weights and generators, ______ Chicago's energy grid.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: In Los Angeles County, California, bicycle paths such as the Legg Lake bicycle path—which is 2.2 miles long—have become an increasingly popular means of travel. Moreover, lawyer and cycling ______ has identified several features of the Los Angeles landscape, like its temperate climate and mostly flat roads, that make the city naturally bike-friendly.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: Within Earth's biomes, there are four main types of desert: arid, semiarid, coastal, and cold. The Kyzylkum Desert in central Asia is a semiarid desert, for     a total area of about 300,000 km2, it is also one of the largest deserts of any type.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: The first documented use of the English word "humiliation" is attributed to poet Geoffrey Chaucer's 1386 work “The Parson's Tale.” However, Chaucer didn't write in Modern English; ______ he wrote in what we now call Middle English, which was commonly used during the period.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

questions.article: Courses on African American history can be found at colleges and universities across the US. For example, historian Jeanne Theoharis teaches courses at Brooklyn College about the Civil Rights and Black Power movements. ______ at Virginia Tech University, historian PaulaMarie Seniors teaches courses about Africana studies.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

questions.article: The Coastal Futures Conservatory in Virginia is known for creating aural representations of ecological data. One such effort combines underwater audio recorded in seagrass beds with data that track rising carbon levels in the seagrass. As carbon levels increase, the audio is correspondingly distorted; __________ listeners can “hear” the changes in the carbon levels.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • In a 2021 study, researchers showed participants an unaltered image of a popular character or logo alongside two slightly altered versions.
  • The Bic logo contains a cartoon man holding a pen.
  • In the first alteration, the man was holding a pencil.
  • In the second alteration, the man was holding nothing.
  • Participants were asked to identify the correct version.
  • 65.3% of participants selected the unaltered image.
questions.question: The student wants to present a finding from the study. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: When participants were asked to identify the correct version of the Bic logo, 65.3% selected the unaltered image.

options.name: B
options.content: Participants were asked to identify the correct version of the Bic logo, which contains a cartoon man holding a pen.

options.name: C
options.content: The Bic logo contains a cartoon man holding a pen, but in one of the altered versions, the man was holding a pencil.

options.name: D
options.content: In a 2021 study, researchers asked participants to identify the correct version of the Bic logo.

questions.correct: When participants were asked to identify the correct version of the Bic logo, 65.3% selected the unaltered image.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Mohs scale of mineral hardness is a ten-point scale that orders minerals by hardness based on their ability to scratch other minerals.
  • Minerals with larger numbers are harder than minerals with smaller numbers and can leave visible scratches on them.
  • Minerals with smaller numbers are softer than minerals with larger numbers and cannot leave visible scratches on them.
  • The mineral fluorite has a Mohs scale number of 4.
  • The mineral quartz has a Mohs scale number of 7.
  • The mineral diamond has a Mohs scale number of 10.
questions.question: The student wants to compare the hardness of the three minerals. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Based on their Mohs scale numbers, diamond (10) is harder than quartz (7), and quartz is harder than fluorite (4).

options.name: B
options.content: A mineral with a Mohs number of 10, like diamond, is harder than one with a Mohs number of 7, like quartz.

options.name: C
options.content: The Mohs scale of mineral hardness can be used to order quartz, fluorite, and diamond by their ability to scratch other minerals.

options.name: D
options.content: Diamond can leave visible scratches on fluorite, which is why diamond has a higher number than fluorite on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness.

questions.correct: Based on their Mohs scale numbers, diamond (10) is harder than quartz (7), and quartz is harder than fluorite (4).

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Trans-Siberian Orchestra (TSO) is a band from the United States that was created in 1996.
  • The band's sound combines the genres of hard rock and classical music, with an epic assembly of nearly fifty musicians that includes over a dozen singers.
  • Musicians are regularly invited to perform with TSO on tour.
  • Electric violinist Mark Wood toured with TSO from 1999 to 2008.
  • Guitarist Bill Hudson toured with TSO in 2015.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize the role Mark Wood played when performing with TSO?

options.name: A
options.content: Musicians Mark Wood and Bill Hudson both toured with the genre-bending band TSO.

options.name: B
options.content: It was from 1999 to 2008 that electric violinist Mark Wood performed with TSO.

options.name: C
options.content: From electric violinist Mark Wood to guitarist Bill Hudson, musicians of all backgrounds have taken the opportunity to perform with TSO.

options.name: D
options.content: From 1999 to 2008, Mark Wood performed with TSO as a touring electric violinist.

questions.correct: From 1999 to 2008, Mark Wood performed with TSO as a touring electric violinist.
